thread.title_full: Oil prices could hit $US20: Goldman | Business Spectator

author: Dow Jones newswires
title: Oil prices could hit $US20: Goldman
text:
Oil prices may need to fall as low as $US20 a barrel to clear the huge surplus in global markets, according to a new report by Goldman Sachs Inc.
The bank isn't expecting that as its base case scenario, but said "the potential for oil prices to fall to such levels...is becoming greater as storage continues to fill."
Still, the US investment bank has made deep cuts to its oil price forecasts, saying that supply will increase in the short-term while demand will continue to fall. (Remember this was the bank whose analyst Arjun N. Murti predicted back in 2008 that oil would hit $US200 a barrel.)
"[Oil prices] will be lower for even longer," analysts at the bank said. "The oil market is even more oversupplied than we had expected."
Goldman sees WTI crude trading at $US45 a barrel in 2016, down from its previous forecast of $US57 a barrel.
It has lowered its forecast for Brent crude, the global benchmark, to $US49.5 in 2016, down from a previous forecast of $US62.
It has slashed its forecasts for crude in one month to $US38 a barrel, from $US45 a barrel, and its three-month forecast has fallen to $US42, from $US49.
After plunging to six-year lows in mid-August, prices steadied in recent sessions. Crude oil is now trading around $US45 a barrel, having lost almost 30 per cent since the beginning of June as concerns over China's growth have dented the demand for the commodity.
Looking ahead, the huge oversupply in global markets will dictate prices.
"The oil market is even more oversupplied than we had expected and we now forecast this surplus to persist in 2016 on further OPEC production growth, resilient non-OPEC supply and slowing demand growth," it said.
Risks are "skewed to even weaker demand" given China's slowdown and the negative impact on other emerging markets, it said.
